{{distinguish|text=stage actress Gertrude Vanderbilt who died in 1960}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney | image = Gertrude_Vanderbilt_Whitney_(c_1909).jpg | caption = circa 1909 | birth_name = Gertrude Vanderbilt | birth_date = {{birth date|1875|1|9}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1942|04|18|1875|01|09}} | death_place = Manhattan, New York, U.S. | parents = [[Cornelius Vanderbilt II]]
[[Alice Claypoole Gwynne]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Harry Payne Whitney]]|1896|1930|reason=d.}} | children = [[Flora Payne Whitney|Flora Whitney Miller]]
[[Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney]]
Barbara Whitney Headley | occupation = Sculptor
[[Private collection|Art collector]] | nationality = American | family = [[Vanderbilt family|Vanderbilt]] }} '''Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney''' (January 9, 1875 – April 18, 1942) was an American [[List of sculptors#W|sculptor]], art patron and collector, and founder in 1931 of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] in New York City. She was a prominent social figure and hostess, who was born into the wealthy [[Vanderbilt family]] and married into the [[Whitney family]]. ==Early life== [[File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney by John Everett Millais (1829-1896).jpg|thumb|left|150px|Gertrude, 13 years of age. ([[John Everett Millais]], 1888)]] Gertrude Vanderbilt was born on January 9, 1875 in New York City, the second daughter of [[Cornelius Vanderbilt II]] (1843–1899) and [[Alice Claypoole Gwynne]] (1852–1934), and a great-granddaughter of "Commodore" [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]]. Her older sister died before Gertrude was born, but she grew up with several brothers and a younger sister. The family's New York City home was an opulent mansion at 742–748 [[Fifth Avenue]].{{cite web|last1=Waldman|first1=Benjamin|title=Then and Now: Remnants of the Vanderbilt Mansion in New York City|url=http://untappedcities.com/2012/02/01/remnants-of-the-vanderbilt-mansion-in-new-york-city/|website=Untapped Cities|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} As a young girl, Gertrude spent her summers in [[Newport, Rhode Island]], at the family's summer home, [[The Breakers]], where she kept up with the boys in all their rigorous sporting activities. She was educated by private tutors and at the exclusive [[Brearley School]] for women students in New York City. She kept small drawings and watercolor paintings in her personal journals which were her first signs of being interested in the arts.{{Cite journal|last=McNeal|first=Patricia|year=2008|title=Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney|journal=Salem Press Biographical EncyclopediaResearch Starters|via=EBSCO}} ===Education and early work=== [[File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney (1920).jpg|right|thumb | Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney in her studio, ca. 1920]] While visiting Europe in the early 1900s, Gertrude Whitney discovered the burgeoning art world of [[Montmartre]] and [[Montparnasse]] in France. What she saw encouraged her to pursue her creativity and become a sculptor. She studied at the [[Art Students League of New York]] with [[Hendrik Christian Andersen]] and [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Earle Fraser]].{{cite book|title=Memorial exhibition; Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney|date=1943|publisher=Whitney museum of American art|location=New York|url=https://archive.org/details/memorialexhibiti00whit|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} Other women students in her classes included [[Anna Vaughn Hyatt]] and [[Malvina Hoffman]].{{cite book|last1=McCarthy|first1=Kathleen D.|title=Women's culture : American philanthropy and art, 1830–1930|date=1991|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=9780226555843|page=221|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xx9SRF1azEIC&pg=PA221|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} In Paris she studied with [[Andrew O'Connor (sculptor)|Andrew O'Connor]]Opitz, Glenn B, editor, Mantle Fielding's Dictionary of American Painters, Sculptors & Engravers, Apollo Book, Poughkeepsie NY, 1986 and also received criticism from [[Auguste Rodin]] in Paris.Friedman, B.H., Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, Doubleday and Company New York, 1978{{cite web|title=The Whitney Museum of American Art|url=http://www.theartstory.org/museum-whitney.htm|website=The Art Story.org|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} Her training with sculptors of public monuments influenced her later direction. Although her catalogs include numerous smaller sculptures,{{cite book|title=Exhibition of sculpture by Gertrude V. Whitney of New York : March 1 to April 15, 1923|date=1923|publisher=Art Institute of Chicago|location=Chicago}}{{cite book|title=Sculpture by Gertrude V. Whitney : [exhibition], March 17 through 28, 1936|date=1936|publisher=M. Knoedler and Co.|url=https://archive.org/details/sculpturebygertr00mkno|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} she is best known today for her monumental works.{{cite book|last1=Marter|first1=Joan|chapter=Whitney, Gertrude Vanderbilt|title=American National Biography Online|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=http://h-net.msu.edu/cgi-bin/logbrowse.pl?trx=vx&list=h-women&month=0403&week=b&msg=ByoYJhvvA7G9pF/jJ1prDA&user=&pw=|accessdate=December 28, 2014}} [[File:Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, II and her daughters, Gladys and Gertrude, having tea in the libtary at the Breakers Newport, Rhode Island.jpg|thumb|left|Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, II and her daughters, Gladys and Gertrude, having tea in the library at the Breakers Newport, Rhode Island, [[William Bruce Ellis Ranken]], 1932]] Her first public commission was ''Aspiration'', a life-size male nude in plaster, which appeared outside the New York State Building at the [[Pan-American Exposition]] in [[Buffalo, New York]], in 1901.{{cite web|title=Pan-American Exposition Sights – Then & Now|url=http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2006/pan_am_sites/nys_building.htm|website=Western New York Heritage Press|accessdate=February 4, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829184838/http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2006/pan_am_sites/nys_building.htm|archivedate=August 29, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney|url=http://panam1901.org/documents/panamwomen/gertrude_whitney.htm|website="Doing the Pan"|accessdate=February 4, 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Heller|first1=Jules|last2=Heller|first2=Nancy G.|title=North American women artists of the twentieth century : a biographical dictionary|date=1995|publisher=Garland Publishing|location=New York|isbn=9780815325840|page=577|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AYxmAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA577|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} Initially she worked under an assumed name, fearing that she would be portrayed as a socialite and her work not taken seriously.{{cite web|last1=Staples|first1=Shelley|title="The Part Played By Women:" The Gender of Modernism at the Armory Show|url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~MUSEUM/Armory/gender.html|website=American Studies Program|publisher=University of Virginia}} Neither her family nor (after her marriage) her husband were supportive of her desire to work seriously as an artist. She once told an artist friend, "Never expect Harry to take your work seriously ... It never has made any difference to him that I feel as I do about art and it never will (except as a source of annoyance)." She believed that a man would have been taken more seriously as an artist, and that her wealth put her in a lose-lose situation: criticized if she took commissions because other artists were more needy, but blamed for undercutting the market for other artists if she was not paid. In 1907, Whitney established an [[Whitney Museum of American Art (original building)|apartment and studio]] in [[Greenwich Village]].{{cite web|title=Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney papers, 1851–1975, bulk, 1888–1942|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/gertrude-vanderbilt-whitney-papers-7107/more|website=Archives of American Art|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} She also set up a studio in [[Passy]], a fashionable Parisian neighborhood in the XVI arrondissement. By 1910 she was exhibiting her work publicly under her own name. ''Paganisme Immortel'', a statue of a young girl sitting on a rock, with outstretched arms, next to a male figure, was shown at the 1910 National Academy of Design.{{cite book|last1=Love|first1=Richard H.|title=Carl W. Peters : American scene painter from Rochester to Rockport|date=1999|publisher=University of Rochester Press|location=Rochester, NY|isbn=9781580460248|page=164|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dIn6EkBlJSUC&pg=PA164}} ''Spanish Peasant'' was accepted at the Paris Salon in 1911, and ''Aztec Fountain'' was awarded a bronze medal in 1915 at the San Francisco Exhibition. Her first solo show occurred in New York City in 1916.{{cite book|last1=Grimm, Jr.|first1=Robert T.|title=Notable American philanthropists : biographies of giving and volunteering|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn.|isbn=978-1573563406|pages=341–344|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vIdSBOiSazsC&pg=PA342|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} The first charity exhibition she organized was in 1914 called the ''50-50 Art Sale''.{{Cite book|title=Women in World History: A Biographical Encyclopedia|last=Cordery|first=Stacy|publisher=Yorkin Publications|year=1999|isbn=|location=Waterford, CT|pages=485}} ==World War I and its aftermath== During [[World War I]], Gertrude Whitney dedicated a great deal of her time and money to various relief efforts, establishing and maintaining a fully operational hospital for wounded soldiers in [[Juilly, Seine-et-Marne|Juilly]], about {{convert|35|km|mi}} northwest of Paris in France. While at this hospital, Gertrude Whitney made drawings of the soldiers which became plans for her memorials in New York City.{{Cite journal|last=Bryant|first=Edward|year=2006|title=Whitney|url=http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T091439pg1.|journal=Oxford University Press|via=Oxford Art Online}} Her work prior to the war had a much less realistic style, which she strayed away from to give the work a more serious feeling. In 1915, her brother [[Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt I|Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt]] perished in the sinking of the [[RMS Lusitania]]. She completed a series of smaller pieces realistically depicting soldiers in wartime,{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=Mary Fanton|title=Sculpture of War: The Work of Gertrude V. Whitney|journal=The Touchstone and the American art student magazine|year=1919|volume=6|pages=188–194|url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006791526}} but her smaller works were not seen as particularly significant during her lifetime. Since her death critics have recognized the expert craftsmanship of her smaller works. File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1919 Touchstone 190 Chateau Thierry.jpg|''Chateau Thierry'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1919 Touchstone 189 His Last Charge.jpg|''His Last Charge'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1919 Touchstone 191 Found.jpg|''Found'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1919 Touchstone 192 Engineers.jpg|''Engineers'' In addition to participating in shows with other artists, Whitney held a number of solo exhibitions during her career. These included a show of her wartime sculptures at her Eighth Street Studio in November 1919; a show at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], March 1 to April 15, 1923; and one in New York City, March 17–28, 1936. The majority of works created in this period of her work were made in her studio in Paris. The Whitney museum of American art held a commemorative show of her works in 1943. ===Sculptures from her 1936 Show=== File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog John.jpg| ''John'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog Salome.jpg | ''Salome'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog Gwendolyn.jpg | ''Gwendolyn'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog Woman and Child.jpg | ''Mother and Child'' File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog frontis.jpg|Untitled File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney 1936 Catalog Sketch.jpg | ''Sketch'' ===Public sculptures=== Following the end of the War, Whitney was also involved in the creation of a number of commemorative sculptures. During the 1920s her works received critical acclaim both in Europe and the United States, particularly her monumental works. During the 1930s the popularity of monumental pieces declined. Whitney's last pieces of public arts were the ''Spirit of Flight'', created for the New York World's Fair of 1939, and the ''Peter Stuyvesant Monument'' in New York City. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney's numerous works in the United States include: * ''Aztec Fountain'' – Pan American Union Building, Washington, D.C., 1912 * ''Fountain of El Dorado'' – 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition, San Francisco, California * Two reliefs on the ''Victory Arch'' – [[Madison Square]], New York City, 1918–19{{cite book|last1=Marter|first1=Joan|title=The Grove encyclopedia of American art|date=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=9780195335798|pages=212–214|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sPGdBxzaWj0C&pg=RA4-PA212&lpg=RA4-PA212|accessdate=December 27, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Capraro|first1=Douglas|title=Daily What?! The Flatiron's Mysterious "Victory Arch" at Madison Square Park|url=http://untappedcities.com/2014/07/29/daily-what-the-flatirons-mysterious-victory-arch-at-madison-square-park/|website=Untapped Cities|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} * ''Washington Heights-Inwood War Memorial'' (World War I) – [[Mitchell Square Park]], [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]], New York City, erected 1922{{cite web|title=Mitchel Square Washington Heights-Inwood War Memorial|url=http://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/mitchel-square/monuments|website=NYC Parks|publisher=New York City Department of Parks & Recreation|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} * ''[[Buffalo Bill Statue|Buffalo Bill – The Scout]]'', William F. Cody Memorial – [[Cody, Wyoming]], dedicated 1924 * ''Untermyer Memorial'', [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)|Woodlawn Cemetery]], New York City, 1925{{cite web|last1=Meier|first1=Allison|title=From Da Bronx to Eternity|url=http://hyperallergic.com/53757/from-da-bronx-to-eternity/|website=Hypoallergenic (Blog)|accessdate=July 3, 2012}} * ''[[The Founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution]]'', a memorial honoring the four founders – Constitution Hall, Washington, D.C., dedicated 1929; Gertrude was a member of the DAR.{{cite web| url=http://www.dar.org/archives/four-founders| title=Founders Memorial| work=Daughters of the American Revolution| accessdate=October 31, 2014}}{{cite web| title=Daughters of the American Revolution, Founders statue at Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.| url=http://www.dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0000930.htm| date=April 20, 2013| accessdate=December 17, 2014| publisher=DC Memorials}} * ''[[Women's Titanic Memorial]]'' – Washington, D.C., unveiled 1931{{cite web|last1=Hanson|first1=Jayna|title=Titanic, an Unsinkable Legacy: Part I, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney's Titanic Memorial and Francis Davis Millet in the Archives of American Art|url=http://blog.aaa.si.edu/2012/04/titanic-unsinkable-legacy-vanderbilt-whitney-womens-memorial-washington-dc.html|website=Archives of American Art Blog|accessdate=April 11, 2012}} * ''Peter Stuyvesant Monument'', New York City, 1936–1939 * ''To the Morrow'', vt. ''Wings'', vt. ''Spirit of Flight'', created for the World's Fair in New York, 1939{{cite web|title=Art – Sculpture – To the Morrow (Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney)|url=http://digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?1654367|website=NYPL Digital Gallery|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} File:'War Panel for the Victory Arch' by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, Wolfsonian-FIU Museum I.JPG|''Victory Arch'', one of two bronze reliefs, New York City File:Mitchel Square World War I memorial.jpg | ''Washington Heights-Inwood War Memorial'' (World War I), New York City File:Titanic Memorial - Washington, D.C..jpg | ''Women's Titanic Memorial'', Washington, D.C. File:The Scout by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney.jpg | ''[[Buffalo Bill Statue|Buffalo Bill - The Scout]]'', [[Cody, Wyoming]] File:Monumento a Cristobal Colón, Huelva..JPG | ''Monument to the Discovery Faith'', [[Huelva]], Spain File:The Three Graces - 1931 - Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney - 06.jpg | ''[[The Three Graces (Whitney)|The Three Graces]]'', [[McGill University]], Montreal, [[Quebec]], Canada File:Founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution cropped.JPG | ''Founders of the Daughters of the American Revolution'', Washington, D.C. File:St-nazaire monument au mort americain.JPG |''A.E.F. Memorial'', [[Saint-Nazaire]], France File:Stuyvesant Square Peter Styvesant statue.jpg | ''Peter Stuyvesant'', New York City File:Patio and central fountain, Pan American Union.jpg | ''Aztec fountain'', Pan American Union Building, Washington, D.C. File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Fountain of El Dorado 1915 Zenis Newton.jpg | ''Fountain of El Dorado'', detail, 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition Whitney's ''[[Titanic Memorial (Washington, D.C.)|Titanic Memorial]]'' is considered by critics as the most important achievement in her artistic career. The statue was built from a $50,000 prize from a competition that she won in 1914. Whitney also created works which are now in other countries, including the ''A.E.F. Memorial'' in St. Nazaire Harbor in [[Saint-Nazaire]], France, 1924.{{cite web|last1=McAuliffe|first1=John|title=St. Nazaire, France Memorial|url=http://gallery.87thinfantrydivision.com/MonumentsMemorialsandMuseums/Europe/St-Nazaire-France-Memorial/2158506_5wdtwt|website=87th Infantry Division Photo Galleries|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} The Government of France purchased a marble replica of the head of the Titanic memorial which is now housed in the [[Musée du Luxembourg]]. Whitney sculpted the [[Christopher Columbus]] memorial, called "Monumento a la Fe Descubridora" (Monument to the Discovery Faith), in [[Huelva]], Spain, 1928–33. With a cubist style, it is one of her biggest works. In 1931 Whitney presented the ''Caryatid Fountain'' to [[McGill University]] in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada,. The fountain is also referred to as ''The Good Will Fountain'', ''The Friendship Fountain'', ''The Whitney Fountain'', '' [[The Three Graces (Whitney)|The Three Graces]]'' and because it consists of three nude males, ''The Three Bares.''.The Good Will Fountain, The Friendship Fountain, The Whitney Fountain, as well as The Three Graces. There is also a bronze version of this fountain in the Washington Square in [[Lima, Peru]].{{cite book|last1=Bicketts|first1=Mónica|title=Lima, paseos por la ciudad y su historia|date=1988|publisher=Diario Expreso|location=Lima}} ==Influence in art== [[File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, Henri.jpg|thumb|[[Robert Henri]], ''Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney,'' 1916]] [[File:Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney.jpg|thumb|Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine, by [[Adolf de Meyer]], January 15, 1917]] Her great wealth afforded her the opportunity to become a patron of the arts, but she also devoted herself to the advancement of women in art, supporting and exhibiting in women-only shows and ensuring that women were included in mixed shows.{{cite book|chapter=Whitney, Gertrude Vanderbilt (1875–1942)|title=Women in World History: A Biographical Encyclopedia|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-2591309854/whitney-gertrude-vanderbilt-18751942.html|website=Encyclopedia.com|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} She supported exhibition of artwork both locally and around the country, including the 1913 [[Armory Show]] in New York.{{cite book|last1=Shircliff|first1=Jennifer Pfeifer|title=Women of the 1913 Armory Show: Their Contributions to the Development of American Modern Art|date=May 2014|publisher=University of Louisville|location=Louisville, Kentucky|url=http://ir.library.louisville.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2321&context=etd|accessdate=November 15, 2014}} Whitney also donated money to the [[Society of Independent Artists]] founded in 1917, which aimed to promote artists who deviated from academic norms. She actively bought works from new artists including the [[Ashcan School]]. In 1922, she financed publication of ''The Arts'' magazine, to prevent its closing. She was the primary financial backer for the "International Composer's Guild," an organization created to promote the performance of modern music.{{cite book|editor-last1=Locke|editor-first1=Ralph P.|title=Cultivating music in America : women patrons and activists since 1860|date=1997|publisher=Univ. of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=9780520083950|pages=239–241|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L4UylL6JGZcC&pg=PA241|accessdate=February 4, 2015}} By 1908, Whitney had opened the [[Whitney Museum of American Art (original building)|''Whitney Studio Gallery'']] in the same buildings as her own studio on West Eighth Street in [[Greenwich Village]]. Artists such as [[Robert Henri]] and [[Jo Davidson]] were invited to showcase their works there.{{cite book|last1=Whitney Museum of American Art|title=Whitney Museum of American Art: history, purpose and activities, with a complete list of works in its permanent collection to June, 1937|date=1937|publisher=Whitney Museum of American Art|location=New York|page=3|url=https://archive.org/details/whitneymuseumofa00whit|accessdate=February 7, 2015}} In 1914, Gertrude Whitney also established the ''Whitney Studio Club'' at 147 West 4th Street, as an artists' club where young artists could meet and talk, as well as exhibit their works. She provided nearby housing many of them, as well as stipends for living costs at home and abroad. The Whitney Studio Club expanded again when its headquarters were moved back from West Fourth Street to West Eighth Street in 1923.{{cite book|last1=Richmond|first1=Lauren|title=Defining the American Vision: The Whitney Museum of American Art's role in changing the landscape of American art history|date=2014|publisher=Wellesley College Honors Thesis Collection|url=http://repository.wellesley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1234&context=thesiscollection|accessdate=February 10, 2015}} Thus, the club expanded both in size and scope of programming. These early galleries would evolve to become Whitney's greatest legacy, the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], on the site of what is now the [[New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture]]. In 1929, Whitney offered the New York [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] the donation of her twenty-five-year collection of nearly 700 American [[modern art]] works and full payment for building a wing to accommodate these works. Her offer was declined because the museum would not take American art, and in 1931, Whitney decided to create her own museum by renovating and expanding on one of her own studios. Whitney appointed [[Juliana R. Force|Juliana Force]], who was formerly her assistant since 1914, to be the museum's first director. The museum aimed to embrace modernism, shifting away from the notions that American art was largely rural and narrow in scope. A colorful recollection of one of her parties celebrating her artist friends was recounted by the artist [[Jerome Myers]]:
Matching it in memory is a party at Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney's, on her Long Island estate, the artists there a veritable catalog of celebrities, painters and sculptors. I can hardly visualize, let alone describe, the many shifting scenes of our entertainment: sunken pools and gorgeous white peacocks as line decorations spreading into the gardens; in their swinging cages, brilliant macaws nodding their beaks at [[George Luks]] as though they remembered posing for his pictures of them; [[Robert Chanler]] showing us his exotic sea pictures, blue-green visions in a marine bathroom; and Mrs. Whitney displaying her studio, the only place on earth in which she could find solitude. Here the artists felt at home, the Whitney hospitality always gracious and sincere.{{cite book| first=Jerome| last=Myers| title=Artist in Manhattan| page=61| publisher=American Artist Group, Inc.| location=New York| year=1940}}
Her [[Whitney Museum of American Art (original building)|Greenwich Village studio]] has been named a National Treasure by the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]], giving it landmark status.{{cite news|last1=Cascone|first1=Sarah|title=Landmark Designations for Whitney and Wyeth Studios|url=http://news.artnet.com/in-brief/landmark-designations-for-whitney-and-wyeth-studios-127418|accessdate=February 4, 2015|work=ArtNet News|date=October 8, 2014}} When Whitney died in 1942, the Whitney Museum of American Art was cleared of the debt it owed her and granted $2.5 million of her money. ==Personal life== At age 21, on August 25, 1896, Gertrude married the extremely wealthy sportsman [[Harry Payne Whitney]] (1872–1930).{{cite book |title=Fortune's Children: The Fall of the House of Vanderbilt |last=Vanderbilt |first=Arthur T., II |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Fortune_s_children.html?id=oCkaAAAAYAAJ |date=August 1989 |publisher=Morrow |location=New York |isbn=0-688-07279-8| accessdate=December 17, 2014}}{{cite book|editor-last1=Magill|editor-first1=Frank N.|title=Dictionary of world biography|date=1999|publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn|location=Chicago|isbn=1579580483|chapter=Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney|pages=3969–3971|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uiQAaGgOChIC&pg=PA3969|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} A banker and investor, Whitney was the son of [[William Collins Whitney]], and his mother, the former Flora Payne, was the daughter of a U.S. Senator and sister of a [[Standard Oil]] Company magnate. Harry Whitney inherited a fortune in oil and tobacco as well as interests in banking. In New York, the couple lived in town houses originally belonging to William Whitney, first at 2 East 57th St., across the street from Gertrude's parents, and after William Whitney's death, at 871 Fifth Avenue.{{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Michael Henry|title=The Most Palatial House in New York: Stanford White's William Collins Whitney Residence!|url=http://mrmhadams.typepad.com/blog/2013/01/the-most-palatial-house-in-new-york-stanford-whites-william-collins-whitney-residence.html|website=Michael Henry Adams, Style and Taste!|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} They also had a country estate in Westbury, Long Island. Gertrude and Harry Whitney had three children: *[[Flora Payne Whitney]] (1897–1986) *[[Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney]] (1899–1992) *Barbara Whitney (1903–1983, {{abbr|m.|married}} 1960 [[George W. Headley]]).{{cite web| url=http://www.nnp.org/nni/Publications/Dutch-American/whitney.html| title=Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney [1875–1942]| publisher=[[New Netherland Institute]]| accessdate=December 17, 2014}} Harry Whitney died of pneumonia in 1930, at age 58, leaving his widow an estate valued at $72 million.Vanderbilt, 354. In 1934, she was at the center of a highly publicized court battle with her sister-in-law, [[Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt]], for custody of her ten-year-old niece, [[Gloria Vanderbilt]]. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney did win custody of her niece at the end of the custody battle. Gertrude Whitney died in 1942, at age 67, and was interred next to her husband in [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)|Woodlawn Cemetery]] in [[The Bronx]], New York City.{{cite news| title=Mrs. H.P. Whitney, sculptor, Is Dead| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B06EEDE153CE33BBC4052DFB2668389659EDE| date=April 18, 1942| work=[[The New York Times]]| accessdate=December 17, 2014}} The reported cause of her death was from a heart condition. Her daughter Flora Whitney Miller assumed her mother's duties as head of the Whitney Museum, and was succeeded by her daughter, Flora Miller Biddle.{{cite news| title=Flora Whitney Miller Is Dead| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/07/19/obituaries/flora-whitney-miller-is-dead-was-art-museum-chairman.html| last=Howe| first=Marvine| date=July 19, 1986| work=The New York Times| accessdate=December 17, 2014}} ===Awards and honors=== * Medal of Award at Panama-Pacific Exhibition for ''Fountain of El Dorado'', 1915 * Associate member of National Sculpture Society, 1916 * Medal from the New York Society of Architects for the Mitchel Square ''World War I memorial'', 1923 * Honorary degree, New York University, 1922 * Honorary degree, Tufts University, 1924 * Bronze medallion at Paris Salon for ''Buffalo Bill – The Scout'', 1924 * French Legion of Honor medal, 1926 * Honorary degree, Rutgers University, 1934 * Elected an honorary member of the [[American Institute of Architects]], 1934 * Honorary degree, Russell Sage College, 1940 * Associate of National Academy of Design, 1940{{cite book|editor-last1=James|editor-first1=Edward T.|editor-last2=James|editor-first2=Janet Wilson|editor-last3=Boyer|editor-first3=Paul S.|title=Notable American Women, 1607–1950 : A Biographical Dictionary|date=1974|publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press.|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=0674627342|pages=601–603|edition=3. print.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rVLOhGt1BX0C&pg=RA2-PA603|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} * Medal of Honor of the National Sculpture Society, 1940{{cite book|editor-last1=Commire|editor-first1=Anne|editor-last2=Klezmer|editor-first2=Deborah|chapter=Whitney, Gertrude Vanderbilt (1875–1942)|title=Women in world history : a biographical encyclopedia|date=1999|publisher=Yorkin Publishers|location=Waterford, Conn.|isbn=0787640808|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-2591309854/whitney-gertrude-vanderbilt-18751942.html|accessdate=December 27, 2014}} ==In popular culture== In the 1982 tele-film, ''Little Gloria ... Happy at Last'', Whitney was portrayed by actress [[Angela Lansbury]], who earned an Emmy nomination for her performance. In 1999, Gertrude Whitney's granddaughter, Flora Miller Biddle, published a family memoir entitled ''The Whitney Women and the Museum They Made''. She was also the subject of [[B. H. Friedman]]'s 1978 ''Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney: A Biography''.{{cite news| last=Weber| first=Bruce| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/books/10friedman.html| title=B. H. Friedman, a Novelist, Art Critic and Pollock Biographer, Is Dead at 84| work=The New York Times| date=January 10, 2011| accessdate=January 11, 2011}} ==Titles from birth to death== *'''1875–1896''': ''Miss'' Gertrude Vanderbilt *'''1896–1930''': ''Mrs.'' [[Harry Payne Whitney]] *'''1930–1942''': ''Mrs.'' Gertrude Whitney ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney}} {{Americana Poster|Whitney, Gertrude Vanderbilt|Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney}} {{Library resources box|by=yes|viaf= 72283828}} * {{cite archive |collection-url= http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/findingaids/whitgert.htm |collection= Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney papers, 1851-1975, bulk 1888-1942 |institution= Smithsonian |location= Archives of American Art }} * {{Find a Grave|6653335}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Whitney, Gertrude Vanderbilt}} [[Category:1875 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:American women sculptors]] [[Category:Burials at Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)]] [[Category:American art collectors]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Art Students League of New York alumni]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:People from Greenwich Village]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of Welsh descent]] [[Category:Vanderbilt family]] [[Category:Whitney family]] [[Category:Whitney Museum of American Art]] [[Category:Artists from New York City]] [[Category:American women in World War I]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century American women artists]] [[Category:1939 New York World's Fair artists]] [[Category:Sculptors from New York (state)]]

{{Infobox company |name = Golden Pages |logo = |type = |foundation = |location_city = |location_country = [[Belgium]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Israel]], [[Netherlands]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Romania]] |location = |locations = |key_people = |area_served = |industry = |products = [[Telephone directory]] of businesses |services = |operating_income = |revenue = |net_income = |num_employees = |parent = |subsid = |slogan = |homepage = |dissolved = |footnotes = |intl = }} [[File:Golden pages Building.JPG|thumb|250px|Golden Pages building in [[Ramat Gan]], [[Israel]]]] '''Golden Pages''' is a company which publishes a [[telephone directory]] of [[business]]es categorized according to product or service. Business listings are printed on yellow paper as opposed to white paper for non-commercial and private phone numbers.
Golden Pages is published in [[Belgium]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Israel]], [[Netherlands]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Bulgaria]] and [[Romania]]. The publishing companies in these countries are not necessarily related.
==Israel== Golden Pages Israel ({{lang-he|דפי זהב}}, ''Dapei Zahav'') was founded by [[Morris Kahn]] in 1968, distributing three directories in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Haifa]] and [[Jerusalem]]. In 2007, the company was sold by Markstone Capital to [[Australian]] firm [[Babcock & Brown]], who purchased 100% of the company.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/golden-pages-ties-the-knot-with-mitchatnim-wedding-planner-1.228759 |title=Golden Pages ties the knot with Mitchatnim wedding planner |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |author=Eran Gabay |date=September 4, 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/business/breaking-news/bcm-acquires-israeli-golden-pages/story-e6frfkur-1111114084305 |title=BCM acquires Israeli Golden Pages |publisher=[[News Limited]] |date=August 1, 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014}}</ref> The company's CEO is Nir Lampert. The largest competitor is [[Bezeq]], which launched a rival internet service in July 2008. The directory lists 250,000 businesses.
The slogan of the company "תן לאצבעות ללכת במקומך" (''Ten LeEtzba'ot Lelekhet BeMkomkha''), parallel to the English "let your fingers do the walking" has become an idiom in Hebrew, and means to do the work with your phone or computer instead of running around.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.babylon.com/definition/let_your_fingers_do_the_walking/Hebrew |title=Let Your Fingers Do The Walking |publisher=[[Babylon]] |accessdate=26 January 2014 |quote=Slogan of Golden Pages; It's possible to save running around by using the telephone (in Hebrew)}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Yellow pages]] *[[Aurec Group]]

Golden Pages Uzbekistan] * [http://www.paginiaurii.ro Golden Pages Romania]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Province of Quebec (1763–91) to [[:Category:Province of Quebec (1763–1791)]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The '''Haldimand Proclamation''' was a [[decree]] that granted land to the [[Iroquois]] who had served on the British side during the [[American Revolution]]. The decree was issued by the Governor of the [[Province of Quebec (1763–1791)|Province of Quebec]], [[Frederick Haldimand]], on October 25, 1784, three days after the [[Treaty of Fort Stanwix (1784)]] was signed between others of the Six Nations and the American government. ==Proclamation text== The text of the proclamation reads:
"Frederick Haldimand, Captain General and Governor General in Chief of the Province of Quebec and Territories depending thereon, General and Commander in Chief of His Majesty's Forces in said Province and the Frontiers thereof --
Whereas His Majesty having been pleased to direct that in consideration of the early attachment to his cause manifested by the Mohawk Indians, and of the loss of their settlement which they thereby sustained-- that a convenient tract of land under his protection should be chosen as a safe and comfortable retreat for them and others of the Six Nations, who have either lost their settlements within the Territory of the American States, or wish to retire from them to the British -- I have at the earnest desire of many of these His Majesty's faithful Allies purchased a tract of land from the Indians situated between the Lakes Ontario, Erie and Huron and I do hereby in His Majesty's name authorize and permit the said [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk Nation]] and such others of the Six Nation Indians as wish to settle in that quarter to take possession of and settle upon the Banks of the River commonly called Ours [Ouse] or Grand River, running into Lake Erie, allotting to them for that purpose six miles deep from each side of the river beginning at Lake Erie and extending in that proportion to the head of the said river, which them and their posterity are to enjoy for ever."{{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|pages=50–51}}
Given under my hand and seal at arms, at the Castle of St Lewis at Quebec, this twenty-fifth day of October one thousand seven hundred and eighty-four and in the twenty-fifth year of the reign of Our Sovereign Lord George The Third by the Grace of God of Great Britain, France and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith and so forth.
Fredk Haldimand
By His Excellency's Command
R. Mathews
==Background== [[Joseph Brant]] and [[Guy Johnson]], who had been ejected from his post as [[Superintendent of Indian Affairs]] a few months before, traveled to London, England in November 1775, on the eve of the [[American Revolution]], to obtain a promise from the Crown that if the Iroquois fought on the British side, they would obtain a land grant in Canada. During and after the [[American Revolution]], American colonists confiscated land and property from those who were Loyalists during the war. The British government compensated both Indian and non-Indian Loyalists with cash payments for their losses. By early 1783, Brant had selected the valley of the [[Grand River (Ontario)|Grand River]] as a place of settlement; in 1784 [[Frederick Haldimand]] agreed. The land was acquired from the [[Mississaugas]] in May 1784, with Lieutenant-Colonel [[John Butler (pioneer)|John Butler]] {{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|pages=43–44}} acting as an agent of purchase on behalf of the government. Later, [[the Crown]] adopted the position that it had failed to obtain title to the entire valley at the time of its purchase from the Mississaugas.{{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|pages=68–69}} ==Interpretation== ===Nature of the grant=== On April 26, 1784, [[Frederick Haldimand]] wrote: ''"The mode of acquiring lands by what is called Deeds of Gift is to be entirely discontinued, for, by the King's instructions, no Private Person, Society, Corporation or colony is capable of acquiring any property in lands belonging to the Indians, either by purchase, or grant or conveyance from the Indians, excepting only where the lands lie within the limits of any colony the soil of which has been vested in Proprietaries or Corporations by grants from the Crown; in which cases such Proprietaries or Corporations only shall be capable of acquiring such property by purchase or grants from the Indians."''Cases Decided on the British North America Act, 1867... Government officials originally interpreted this grant as prohibiting the Indians from leasing or selling the land to anyone but the government. [[Joseph Brant]] countered that Haldimand had promised the Indians freehold land tenure equal to that enjoyed by the colony's Loyalist settlers. As freeholders, the Indians could lease or sell land to the highest bidder. In 1793, [[John Graves Simcoe|Lieutenant Governor Simcoe]] stated that the Indians could not lease their land since British subjects could only lease land from British subjects. [[Joseph Brant]] considered the right to lease or sell land as a litmus test for Indian sovereignty. The crown said that the grant was for all members of the Six Nations, but Brant said the land should only be for those members of the Six Nations who were living on the land. ===Extent of the lands=== [[File:Thomas Ridout map of Grand River Indian Lands, 1821.jpg|thumb|Thomas Ridout survey of 1821]] Although the overall limits of the lands mentioned in the proclamation were clearly defined,"extending in that proportion to the head of the said river", the Crown contended that the grant was limited by the extent of land they had previously purchased and that they could not grant land which they did not already own.{{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|page=67}} In May 1784, Haldimand had purchased a tract of land from the [[Mississaugas]], which was referred to in the grant as generally "situated between the Lakes Ontario, Erie and Huron". In fact, the [[Source (river or stream)|head]] of the [[Grand River (Ontario)|Grand River]] is located some thirty miles beyond the limits of land that the Crown maintained that it had previously purchased from the Mississaugas.[http://www.grandriver.ca/index/document.cfm?sec=74&sub1=6&sub2=0 Map of Grand River watershed] In 1791 at the request of the Six Nations, an initial survey was completed. It was agreed between [[Joseph Brant]], Henry Tekarihoga, and other chiefs with the Nassau District land board that the middle of the grant should not follow the exact windings of the river, but that it should be drawn from an easterly bend near the river's mouth straight to the Mohawk village.Kelsay pg. 555 Although the government alleges that the Six Nations agreed to the accuracy of the information gathered during the 1791 survey, the resulting documentation in the form of a map signed by the Land Board and the Six Nation chiefs was subsequently "believed lost or destroyed".{{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|page=57}} The Crown's position was that the extent of the land was as determined in the subsequent [[Thomas Ridout]] survey of 1821, drawing a northern boundary near the present location of [[Elora, Ontario]], referred to at the time of the survey as "The Falls".{{cite book |title=The Valley Of The Six Nations|editor= Charles M. Johnston |year=1964 |publisher=The Champlain Society For The Government of Ontario, University of Toronto Press|isbn=|page=128 [map insert]}} In this survey, the size of the grant was described as {{convert|674910|acre|km2|1|abbr=on}} As early as July 4, 1819, Six Nations chief [[John Brant (Mohawk chief)|John Brant]] (''Tekarihoga''), son of Joseph Brant, in a speech at a council held near present-day [[Hamilton, Ontario]] to deal with land issues, stated, "We are surprised to find that [the] Government says that we own the Lands to the Falls only as we have the Writings to prove otherwise. We have them here and are ready to produce them." ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *[http://link.library.utoronto.ca/champlain/item_record.cfm?Idno=9_96899&lang=eng&query=The%20AND%20Valley%20AND%20Of%20AND%20The%20AND%20Six%20AND%20Nations.&searchtype=Title&startrow=1&Limit=All|Johnston, Charles M.,''The Valley Of The Six Nations: A Collection of Documents on the Indian Lands of the Grand River'', 1964, University of Toronto Press] * Indian Records, R.G. 10, Ser. 2, XV, 132-33, PAC; B222,106, PAC * Graymont, Barbara, ''The Iroquois in the American Revolution'', 1972, {{ISBN|0-8156-0083-6}} * Kelsey, Isabel, ''Joseph Brant 1743-1807 Man of Two Worlds'', 1984, {{ISBN|978-0-8156-0182-1}} * Taylor, Alan, ''The Divided Ground'', 2006, {{ISBN|0-679-45471-3}} * ''Cases Decided on the British North America Act, 1867 in The Privy Council, The Supreme Court of Canada and the Provincial Courts'', 1892, Warwick & Sons, Toronto [[Category:First Nations history in Ontario]] [[Category:Indian reserves in Ontario]] [[Category:Grand River (Ontario)]] [[Category:1784 in British law]] [[Category:Proclamations]] [[Category:Province of Quebec (1763–1791)]]

{{about|the final report issued by the Hamoodur Rahman Commission|other uses|Hamoodur Rahman Commission}} [[File:Pakistan 1971.png|thumb|250px|Pakistan in Asia: Pakistan's historical map before or prior to 1971.]]
The '''Hamoodur Rahman Commission Report''' (or '''War Report'''<ref name="BBC Pakistan Bureau">{{cite news|last1=BBC|title=Bangladesh requests war report|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/903149.stm|accessdate=24 August 2016|work=BBC|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC Pakistan Bureau|date=30 August 2000}}</ref>) contains the [[Government of Pakistan]]'s official and classified papers of the events leading up to [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|loss]] of [[East Pakistan]] and the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971|1971 war]] with [[India]].<ref name="Story of Pakistan reports">{{cite web|last=et. al|title=The Hamood-ur-Rahman Commission Report|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/the-hamood-ur-rahman-commission-report/|publisher=Story of Pakistan reports|accessdate=14 June 2013|date=1 January 2003}}</ref> Initially, there were 12 copies of the report prepared by the [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] [[Hamoodur Rahman]]; all over destroyed except one. That single report was handed over to the [[Government of Pakistan|government]], which forbade its publication at the time.<ref name="Story of Pakistan reports"/> The report was leaked eventually by the [[India Today|Indian]] and the Pakistani [[Pakistani newspapers|newspapers]], including [[Dawn (newspaper)|''Dawn'']], drawing the attention of the public to its front pages in 2000. An editorial entitled, "''Gen Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan - 4''" written by [[Cowasjee, Ardeshir|Ardeshir Cowasjee]] on the basis of the Hamoodur Rahman Commission Report, demonstrated that "three men principally (had been) responsible for the loss, at the end of 1971, of half of Jinnah's Pakistan— end of story."<ref name="Dawn Newspapers (archives)">{{cite news|last=Cowasjee|first=Ardeshir|title=Gen Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan - 4|url=http://archives.dawn.com/weekly/cowas/20000917.htm|accessdate=14 June 2013|newspaper=Dawn Newspapers (archives)|date=17 September 2000|language=}}</ref>
Originally, it was thought that the [[Government of Pakistan]] had declassified the Report in 2002 and was made it available to the public as [[public domain]] whereas it was free to download on the internet. However, it was reported to be a "Supplementary Report" which was created after the prisoners of war returned after two years.<ref name="Yale University Press, Jones">{{cite book|last1=Jones|first1=Owen Bennett|title=Pakistan: Eye of the Storm|date=2003|publisher=Yale University Press, Jones|isbn=0300101473|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t8iYEgPYG_EC&pg=PA171&dq=hamoodur+Rahman+West+Pakistani+families&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDtoH7jdbOAhUQ8GMKHTqLAmgQ6wEIHzAA#v=onepage&q=hamoodur%20Rahman%20West%20Pakistani%20families&f=false|accessdate=22 August 2016|language=en}}</ref> The [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission#First Report|First Report]] is never published nor is accessible to anyone.<ref name="Hamoodur Rehman Commission Report">{{cite web|format=PDF|title=Hamoodur Rahman Commission Report (Supplementary Report)|url=http://www.pppusa.org/Acrobat/Hamoodur%20Rahman%20Commission%20Report.pdf|accessdate=14 June 2013|publisher=Pakistan People's Party USA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304011310/http://www.pppusa.org/Acrobat/Hamoodur%20Rahman%20Commission%20Report.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2012|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Classified information|Classified information in Pakistan]] {{Bangladesh Liberation War}} [[Category:Non-fiction graphic novels]] [[Category:Pakistani philosophical literature]] [[Category:1972 in Pakistan]] [[Category:2000 in Pakistan]] [[Category:Classified documents]] [[Category:Pakistani historical documents]] [[Category:Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] [[Category:Whistleblowing]] [[Category:Dawn (newspaper)]] [[Category:Reports of the Government of Pakistan]] [[Category:Government of Pakistan secrecy]] [[Category:1972 documents]]
